title-group.article-title: The Take-Up of Multiple Means-Tested Benefits by British Pensioners: Evidence from the Family Resources Survey

abstract.p: Non-take-up of means-tested benefits among pensioners is of long-standing concern. It has assumed increased importance from October 2003 with the introduction of the new means-tested pension credit to which about half of pensioners are expected to be entitled. We use Family Resources Survey data from April 1997 to March 2000 to investigate patterns of pensioner take-up of income support (IS) (subsequently renamed the minimum income guarantee and now subsumed in pension credit), housing benefit (HB) and council tax benefit (CTB). Although 36 per cent of pensioners in our sample failed to claim their entitlements to at least one of these benefits, only 16 per cent failed to claim amounts worth more than 10 per cent of their disposable income. Generally, take-up is high where entitlement is high. But there are exceptions which may reflect the claims process and/or a greater degree of social stigma associated with IS than with HB or CTB.

p.mixed-citation: The 'guarantee credit' element of the new pension credit is calculated in a similar manner, although the upper capital limit has been abolished and notional income from capital is calculated at the rate of £1 for every £500 of capital above the lower threshold.
Note that cases with incomes above the appropriate means-tested level can be, and are, correctly identified as not entitled to benefit even if capital data are missing.
Hancock and Barker (forthcoming) describe the process as applied to income and capital. For this paper, recorded amounts of rent, council tax, HB and CTB were treated similarly.

0f these, 13 cases were awaiting the outcome of a claim for CTB and not entitled to IS or HB, eight cases were receiving HB and CTB and awaiting a claim for IS, six were receiving CTB, not entitled to HB and awaiting a claim for IS, and five were entitled to but not receiving IS and were awaiting a CTB claim. Smaller numbers fell into each of the other categories. None was awaiting a claim for all three benefits.

Cases receiving HB and/or CTB but not taking up entitlements to IS were examined closely for evidence that they were incorrectly calculated to be entitled to IS due to measurement error in their income or capital. Of such cases, 65 per cent were receiving maximum HB and/or CTB which is consistent with income and capital low enough to qualify for IS. The remainder were receiving less than maximum HB and CTB. This could result from measurement error in income or capital which would indicate that they might not be entitled to IS. Alternatively, it could be the consequence of measurement error in rent or council tax, which would not in itself shed doubt on their entitlement to IS.

Cases with zero or negative income are excluded. An alternative measure of the significance of non-take-up would be to express unclaimed entitlements as a proportion of potential income, i.e. income as constructed here plus unclaimed entitlements. This would avoid the need to exclude negative and zero incomes since the denominator would always be strictly positive. However, this alternative would probably be harder to interpret.
Since owner-occupiers are not eligible for HB. they are more likely than renters to be entitled to only one benefit, that being CTB.
The general picture and conclusions are very similar for a sample of all pensioner units (based on 1999-2000 FRS with no error correction and using POLIMOD), as shown in Figure B1 in Appendix B.

Note that Figure 4 conditions take-up on other receipts rather than other entitlements, despite the endogeneity of other receipts. The reason for conditioning in this way is to illustrate the pattern of partial take-up and to highlight some anomalies in the combinations of benefits claimed. See the subsequent discussion.

We do not include any allowance for the benefits, such as spectacle vouchers, that are 'passported' via IS (see Sutherland (2003b) for a discussion of what can and cannot be deduced from the FRS on the value of these benefits).
Note that these groups are not disjoint. For example, some of the individuals in the group (ISICTB; n=522) will also appear as non-take-up cases in the groups (HBIIS.CTB ) and ( HBICTB ).
The HBIIS group has a lower take-up rate, but is numerically negligible.

There are some combinations of entitlement that are rare or impossible (for example, IS and HB but not CTB). However, these cause no modelling difficulty, since the take-up model conditions on the entitlement configuration. The consequence is simply that there are some empty cells in the joint distribution of the exogenous explanatory variables.

Since the information would have been provided to local authorities, which administer HB and CTB, the Data Protection Act inhibits this process by placing restrictions on information sharing between local authorities and the Department for Work and Pensions, which administers IS / MIG / pension credit.
These are arrived at by noting that (in a large sample) Ti = E(r) / [E(r)+E(e*(l-r))] and Ti = E(re*) / E(e*), where e is the FRS simulated entitlement status, and then doing a little algebra.
